Dear Amy Elizabeth Harding:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12316 Personal possessions
Section (1) An agency’s personal possessions policy shall, at a minimum,
Description address both of the following:
(a) Assuring that a child has a right to have his or her personal
possessions during placement with a foster family and when
leaving the foster family.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency refuses to give foster child personal belongings when
moving from one placement to another. This has been an ongoing
issue for more than 7 weeks and has still not been returned.
Agency told the previous foster parents to get rid of child's
personal belongings despite significant monetary and sentimental
value.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
On 7/20/2023 Foster Parent, who is also the Complainant, was
interviewed by phone. She stated she had belongings of a youth
who was placed in her home for over 6 weeks after the youth
moved to a different placement. Foster Parent A provided the
following timeline of events during her interview:
• 6/5/2023 - Youth A, who was placed Foster Parent’s home,
was transported by Foster Care Worker to a new
placement at which time the youth only packed and
brought one bag of her belongings.
• 6/16/2023 Foster Care Worker returned to Foster Parent’s
home for more of Youth A’s belongings; however, she did
not take all of the belongings and scheduled to return for
them on 6/20/2023.
• 6/20/2023 Foster Parent reported Foster Care Worker
canceled the pickup and rescheduled for 6/29/2023.
• 6/29/2023 Foster Care Worker did not show up and
reported to Foster Parent she had forgotten about the
pickup. She rescheduled for 7/5/2023.
• 7/5/2023 Foster Care Worker told Foster Parent the
agency’s “big car” would be available the following day so
she would be able to take all of Youth A’s belongings then.
• 7/6/2023 Foster Care Worker texted Foster Parent that she
would be able to come get the belongings that day but
texted to cancel later in the afternoon. Foster Care Worker
texted Foster Parent that she could come the following
day, 7/7/2023 after a morning court hearing.
2

• 7/7/2023 Foster Parent texted Foster Care Worker asking
when she was coming to which Foster Care Worker
responded court was taking longer than expected but she
would still make it to the home that day. Foster Parent
texted Foster Care Worker multiple times in the afternoon
to which she received no response. Foster Care Worker
never showed up.
• 7/11/202 Foster Parent spoke to Foster Care Supervisor
about Youth A’s belonging because she felt Youth A
deserved to have them. Foster Care Supervisor told Foster
Parent she could get rid of some of the belongings such as
a pink office chair and a rug of Youth A’s because Foster
Care Supervisor did not think they would fit in a vehicle and
Youth A did not need them. Foster Parent reported that the
rug was a birthday gift to Youth A and the office chair was
something Youth A used daily, carrying it up and down the
stairs throughout the day. Foster Parent kept “pushing” to
Foster Care Supervisor that Youth A deserved her
belongings to which Foster Care Supervisor agreed and
told Foster Parent she would get all of the belongings to
Youth A by the end of that week. Foster Parent reported
she did not hear anything the rest of that week.
• 7/20/2023, prior to this scheduled interview, Foster Care
Worker and Foster Care Supervisor showed up for Youth
A’s belongings. Foster Parent reported Foster Care
Supervisor did not think the chair would fit in the car they
brought and again told Foster Parent to throw it away, but
Foster Parent refused, and the chair did fit in the vehicle.
Foster Parent reported in the weeks it has taken Foster Care
Worker to pick up Youth A’s belonging, Youth A has texted Foster
Parent asking for her things. Foster Parent is concerned Foster
Care Worker will not bring Youth A all of her things right away and
may discard some of them despite Youth A asking her specifically
for those items.
On 7/27/2023 Foster Care Worker was interviewed via Microsoft
Teams. She reported Foster Parent gave immediate notice to
have Youth A moved from her home on 5/29/2023. Youth A went
AWOL from the placement the same day and was picked up by
Foster Care Worker and a coworker after Youth A’s grandfather
had called and told Foster Care Worker where to find Youth A.
Foster Parent asked Foster Care Worker to put Youth A in respite
for the evening which Foster Care Worker felt was appropriate as
3

Foster Care Worker had already started a search for a new
placement. Youth A brought the bag she had already packed
when she ran away to the respite provider’s home. Foster Care
Worker returned to Foster Parent’s home the following week and
filled her car with Youth A’s belongings which she dropped off to
Youth A. Foster Care Worker stated that not everything would fit
her car, so she made an appointment to return for the rest of the
belongings the following week. The following week, she asked
Foster Parent if she could reschedule because Youth A had pink
eye. She rescheduled for 7/7/2023 but ended up in court longer
than expected. She reported she called Foster Parent after the
court hearing to let her know she wouldn’t be able to make it that
day. She stated she would take a screenshot of that call and text it
as Foster Parent stated Foster Care Worker did not call her that
day; however, she did.
Foster Care Worker stated Foster Parent came into the office and
told Foster Care Supervisor that Foster Care Worker was not
calling her back after which Foster Care Worker reached out to
her and scheduled a time to pick up the belongings with a bigger
car. Foster Care Worker reported she picked up the belongings on
7/20/2023 and dropped them off to Youth A on 7/21/2023. Foster
Care Worker reported she never told Foster Parent to throw any of
the items away, but Foster Care Supervisor did tell her to throw a
chair away because it was broken and not fitting into the car.
Foster Care Worker reported the chair ended up fitting into the
car, but Youth A threw it away after it was brought to her.
On 8/1/2023 Foster Care Supervisor was interviewed via
Microsoft Teams. Foster Care Supervisor reported when Youth A
was initially replaced from Foster Parent’s home, she provided a
list of belonging she wanted. Foster Care Supervisor reported they
were able to get two car loads of belongings to Youth A, but there
were still a lot of belonging at Foster Parent’s home. She stated
Foster Care Worker was working on picking up the belongings but
things kept coming up so she couldn’t do it. Foster Care
Supervisor stated there were items such as broken doll parts,
several rocks, a “huge” rug, a broken chair, and a saddle. She
reported she tried to get Foster Parent to get rid of items such as
the broken items and rocks and told Foster Parent they would buy
Youth A a new chair. Foster Parent was adamant that Youth A
had a right to her belonging, so everything was loaded into the car
and brought to Youth A who then proceeded to throw away the
items she no longer wanted. Foster Care Supervisor stated that it
did take longer than they would have liked to pick up Youth A’s
belongings and Foster Care Worker does take responsibility for
4

that. She stated she understands that Youth A has a right to
decide what she wants to keep and throw away.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
The following case contacts were reviewed in the youth’s
electronic case record:
6/1/2023: Worker picked up small bag of clothes
6/2/2023: Worker text to Foster Parent asking to pick up clothes.
6/2/2023: Worker dropped the clothes to Youth A who said they
were dirty and too small, but she had enough until she moved
6/15/2023: Worker picked up what youth requested, couldn’t fit all
belongings in her car
6/20/2023: Worker cancelled picking up items because youth has
pink eye and no stable placement
6/29/2023: Worker cancelled picking up items due to another case
emergency
7/7/2023: Worker unable to pick up items due to termination
hearing lasting longer than expected
7/20/2023: Worker picked up items from Foster Parent, Supervisor
suggested throwing some items away
7/21/2023: Worker dropped off items to Youth A
Analysis The agency staff did not assure the youth had a right to her
belongings when leaving a foster home and being placed in
another home by not providing her with all of her belongings for
several weeks. Additionally, the agency supervisor suggested the
foster parent throw away some of the youth’s belongings without
the youth’s knowledge.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12409 Education policy.
Section (1) An agency’s education policy shall ensure that, within 5 school
Description days of placement, an agency shall provide for the enrollment of
each child of school age, as defined by state law, into a school
program.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency prevented child from returning to school for over a month.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
On 7/20/2023 Foster Parent, who is also the Complainant, was
interviewed by phone. She reported Youth B, who was placed in
her home after his release from a juvenile detention center was
not enrolled in school for a month after the placement. Initially,
upon placement, Foster Care Worker told Foster Parent she
5

would get Youth B enrolled in a new school because he could not
continue to attend the same online school he had attended while
in detention. Foster Care Worker then told her she was trying to
enroll him in an online school, but that school was in the middle of
testing, so she would enroll him at a later date. Foster Parent
asked again about Youth B attending the same online school as
he did while in detention and Foster Care Worker told Foster
Parent, she was certain he could not. After another week had
passed, Foster Parent called the school Youth B had been
attending in detention and was told that he could have remained in
that school and continued his online classes and all that needed to
be done was some paperwork to get him re-enrolled. The day
Foster Parent was supposed to bring the paperwork to the school
her car broke down and Foster Care Worker told her she could not
help. Foster Parent stated she found a way to get Youth B and the
paperwork to the school, which was on a Friday, after which Youth
B started back at the school the following Monday.
On 7/27/2023 Foster Care Worker was interviewed via Microsoft
Teams. She reported when Youth B was in detention, he was
attending online school. When he left detention, he did not want to
go back to in person school. Foster Care Worker stated there
were 2 weeks left of school and she reached out to the online
school he was attending in detention, and they told her he could
not remain enrolled there. She stated she called an online school
who said they could enroll him, but exams were the following
week. She stated she called another online school who told her he
could wait and start the summer school session in June. Foster
Care Worker stated that school was giving her trouble with
paperwork, so she called the school he had been attending in
detention again at which time they told her he could go there.
When asked to clarify it was her or if it was Foster Parent who
called and found out he could go there, Foster Care Worker stated
she and Foster Parent were “working together” to find Youth B a
school and Foster Parent called the school to get Youth B’s
transcripts for the new school at which time they told her he could
continue to go there. She stated she then called herself to confirm.
Foster Care Worker stated Youth B was not enrolled in school for
a total of 3 weeks.
On 8/1/2023 Foster Care Supervisor was interviewed via Microsoft
Teams. She reported when Youth B left detention he was behind
in credits and wanted to do online school to catch up. Foster Care
Supervisor reported that he could not stay in the school he was
attending while in detention because he was no longer in
detention. She stated Foster Care Worker got him enrolled in a
6

new school when he went to the foster home. Foster Care
Supervisor was then told Youth B is attending the same school he
was attending in detention and could have, in fact, remained
enrolled at that school the entire time and it was Foster Parent
who called the school and got him back in. She was also told
Youth B was not enrolled in school for at least 3 weeks after
leaving detention. Foster Care Supervisor responded she did not
know any of that information.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
The following documentation was reviewed in Youth B’s electronic
case record:
• Placement History: Detention 8/24/22-4/11/23
Foster Parent 4/11/23-5/14/23
AWOL 5/14/23-current
• School Enrollment History:
Muskegon ISD 8/11/2021 – current
On 8/16/2023 I received and reviewed a copy of the agency
education policy which states youth must be enrolled in school
within 5 school days of placement.
Analysis Agency staff did not provide for the enrollment of Youth B within 5
days of placement as required per policy.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12404 Placement.
Section (4) An agency shall consider all of the following factors in selecting
Description an appropriate placement for a child:
(c) Expressed preferences of the child.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency risked child safety by ignoring child's request to be moved
to another placement and threats of cutting and running away.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
On 7/20/2023 Foster Parent, who is also the Complainant, was
interviewed by phone. She reported Youth B, who is Youth A’s
brother, ran away from the foster home after turning 18 to live with
his girlfriend. Foster Parent stated this was hard on Youth A who
then said she wanted to move to a new placement and not did not
want to be adopted by Foster Parent. Youth A told Foster Parent
she had talked to Foster Care Worker about wanting to be moved
but didn’t feel heard. Foster Parent reported that she was sick on
5/30/2023 and Youth A used that opportunity to run away from the
home on her bike. Foster Parent stated Youth A left a note at the
home that stated she had run away and if she was brought back
7

to Foster Parent’s home, she would run again. Foster Care
Worker found Youth A and brought her to a respite placement for
the evening. While at the respite home, she told the respite
provider she had been cutting herself. Youth A showed the respite
provider where she had been cutting but there were no marks.
The following day, 5/31/2023, there was an FTM held which
Foster Care Worker, Foster Parent, and Youth A’s grandfather
attended. Foster Parent reported everyone agreed during the
meeting that it was not a good safety plan to return Youth A to
Foster Parent’s home due to her threats to continue to run and
allegations she had been cutting in the home. Foster Parent
stated she was contacted by Foster Care Worker the following day
and was told she would have to take Youth A back for one night
because Youth A had already been in respite too long. Foster
Parent stated she told Foster Care Worker it was not anyone’s
best interest for Youth A to return to her home as everyone had
agreed it was not a safe situation and Foster Parent was
struggling with pregnancy related illness. Foster Parent stated
Foster Care Worker became aggressive and threatened to file a
complaint on the foster family if they refused to take Youth A for
the night. Foster Parent stated she felt bullied. Ultimately, Youth A
was able to stay with the respite provider before being placed into
another home.
On 7/27/2023 Foster Care Worker was interviewed via Microsoft
Teams. She reported Youth A had been with foster parents who
were interested in adopting her until they found out the foster
mother was pregnant and asked for Youth A to be moved without
notice on 5/29/2023. Youth A went AWOL the same day. Foster
Parent told Foster Care Worker Youth A had left a note stating
she didn’t want to live in the home anymore and Youth A had
made threats of self-harm. Foster Care Worker was contacted by
Youth A’s grandfather who told her where Youth A was after which
Foster Care Worker and a coworker picked up Youth A. Youth A
then told Foster Care Worker, she was frustrated with everything
going on at the foster home and that she had been thinking about
self-harm while there. She then told Foster Care Worker she had
been cutting her arm and showed Foster Care Worker, but there
were no marks. Foster Care Worker reported Foster Parent
thought it best for Youth A to go to a respite provider due to her
threats of self-harm and note stating she would run again if
returned to the home. Foster Care Worker stated she felt that was
reasonable and she was already looking for a new placement. A
day or two later, an FTM was held during which Foster Care
Worker told Foster Parent that she would have to take Youth A
back since Youth A had reached the maximum number of nights
8

in respite and, per policy, she had 14 days to find a new
placement for Youth A. Foster Parent brought up her concerns
related to Youth A’s threats and Foster Care Worker told her the
family had to take her back. Foster Parent told her she was not
able to provide the required level of supervision due to Foster
Parent being ill, which Foster Care Worker did not understand.
Foster Care Worker stated she told Foster Parent she would be
reported for not taking the youth back into her home. Foster Care
Worker stated that she had previously agreed with Foster Parent
that the placement was not in the youth or family’s best interest.
Foster Care Worker stated that a variance was requested in order
for Youth A to be placed back with one of her previous placements
who was at capacity. That variance was approved, so Youth A did
not have to return to Foster Parent’s home.
On 8/1/2023 Foster Care Supervisor was interviewed via Microsoft
Teams. She stated Youth A had run away using her bike in the
morning. Once she was found, she was brought to the office
where she said she was not happy in her placement. Foster Care
Supervisor stated Foster Parent refused to take Youth A back
because they were concerned about the threats, she had made so
Youth A was placed in a respite home. After a few days, the youth
agreed to go back to Foster Parent’s home for one night to avoid
exceeding the number of allowed days in respite, but Foster
Parent stated she couldn’t provide the level of supervision the
agency was asking of her to provide for the youth’s safety. Foster
Care Supervisor stated she believes it was Foster Care Worker
who then told the family the agency would call CPS if they would
not take Youth A back. Foster Care Supervisor stated she may
have said it differently herself but thinks it might be agency policy
to call CPS if a family will not take a youth back into their home.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
The following documentation was reviewed in the youth’s
electronic case record:
• Placement History:
Youth A with Foster Parent from 8/26/2022 to 5/30/2023
• Case Contact:
o 5/29/2023 Foster Parent gave notice to find new
placement for Youth A
o 5/30/2023 – Foster Parent called to report Youth A
was AWOL. Foster Parent was ill in the morning and
had not checked on Youth A, who was working on
her homeschooling until now (between 10 & 11 AM)
9

o 6/12023 - Worker called and told Foster Parent that
Youth A would go to a respite provider for 4 days
then had to come back to Foster Parent since the 14
days since notice to find new placement was given
has not yet passed. Foster Parent told Foster Care
Worker that her husband was working and Foster
Parent is pregnant and can’t provide 24/7
supervision of Youth A.
• Family Team Meeting Documentation:
5/31/2023 Documentation stated Youth A was to remain in
her current placement.
On 8/16/2023 Deputy Director sent an email stating that the
agency does not have a policy requiring staff to call CPS about
foster families who refuse to maintain placement or take a youth
back into their home after AWOL, regardless of circumstance.
Analysis Agency staff did not consider the expressed interest of the youth
when contacting the foster parent to threaten them with filing an
abuse/neglect complaint when they stated they could not continue
to provide placement for a youth after the youth stated she would
continue to run away from the home and attributed self-harm
thoughts to circumstances in the home.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
August 16, 2023
